comments_by_consensus.content: Effective cycling infrastructure requires a network, not isolated branches.
Toronto has adversarial dynamics between cars and bikes.
The province paying to remove bike lanes may discourage local efforts for safer cycling.
Cycling improves health outcomes and quality of life for non-cyclists by improving air quality and reducing noise
Streets are for life, not just for passing through and bike lanes support local life.
Instead of continuing to comission studies, Toronto should expedite actions and learn from the successes & failures of other municipalities.
Whether to remove bike lanes should be based on data, not politics, not assumptions.
Suburban/out-of-city drivers should want more bike lanes and cyclists, because they clear the road for them
Cars shouldn't be the only transportation method
Building more physically durable bike infrastructure, like the College bike lanes, also makes it more politically durable
If Toronto continues to densify while relying on cars, traffic will become completely untenable
We need to increase the capacity of our existing road space by investing in more space efficient modes like transit and bike lanes
Removing bike lanes does not remove cyclists from the road. It just makes it less safe to bike.
prioritize getting people out of the single person auto and into other forms of transit
Bike infrastructure allows kids to learn to cycle early, making them more likely to be lifelong cyclists
The rapid drop in battery size and cost will lead to e-bikes making cycling more accessible to wide swathes of the population
Toronto is expensive and we should invest in low-cost transportation like biking and public transit to make our city accessible and fair
The best way to reduce traffic is reducing the # of cars; the best way to do that is to build infrastructure for other forms of transport
Some major congestion in Toronto is caused by inefficient road design - street parking allowed on Bayview, Allen Road intersection, etc.
Bike lanes on busy roads promote eco-friendly transportation but require careful planning.
There is no way for Toronto to meet its climate goals without a significant transition away from driving
cars are the cause of traffic
The province being adversarial with city means less incentive for city to run reversible pilots.
No amount of additional car lanes will reduce traffic, because more car lanes lead to more people driving
Cities like Paris prove that rapid and positive changes in bike infrastructure are possible!
Not every car trip can be a bike trip. However, reducing the trips that do not need to be taken by car, can reduce traffic for trips that do
Removing bike lanes risks pushing cyclists into more dangerous traffic situations.
Cars should not park or stop on bike lanes as bikes should not park or stop on car lanes
For bike lanes (cycle tracks) to be effective they need to be maintained, especially in winter.
Downtown bike lanes have higher possible throughput than downtown car lanes
Bike infrastructure is easier and cheaper to maintain than car infrastructure, because bikes damage roads far less than cars
correlation between bike lanes and traffic isn't straightforward. need ways to estimate the impact and test assumptions of how they interact
Cities should have full authority to decide on bike lanes based on local needs.
Bike lanes only work/ are safe if planned across the city, connecting all streets. Without puts everyone in danger.
Cars are space inefficient compared to cycling or mass public transit.
Consulting the province before adding bike lanes could slow down important city-level changes.
Efficient traffic flow for cars is important, but not at the cost of bike lane safety.
Municipal budgets go farther supporting cycle tracks than more automobile/truck lanes.
Itâ€™s critical that cities and the province work together to create safe transportation options.
Policies should be update to accommodate Bicycles and other mode of transportation
Bicycles and other mode of transportation have just as much authority on roads as cars
City planning should prioritize reducing emissions by supporting safe bike infrastructure.
Removing paid parking spaces on roads would have a greater impact improving traffic congestion than removing bike lanes.
Bike lanes can reduce traffic by getting people onto bikes who would otherwise drive.
Safety is the number one barrier for cycling adoption, and connected bike infrastructure is critical for cyclists feeling safe
Education on rules, responsibilities and regulation on biking within the city by all citizens to make it more effective and safer for all.
prioritize getting people out of the single person auto and into mass transit, and human powered vehicles, cars are the cause of traffic
Bicycles and other mode of transportation have just as much authority on roads as cars, policies should be update to accomodate them
Bike lanes can be maintained in winter just like car lanes are maintained
Ebikes that can go beyond the regulated speed are dangerous for pedestrians and cars
Major streets should accommodate both cars and bikes to improve mobility for everyone.
bikes are the future
My experience is that for some reason Toronto has really adversarial dynamics between cars and bikes, worse than other cities.
The province being adversarial with city means less incentive for city to run reversible pilots, and so is bad for province's own goals
Existing bike lanes should remain in place.
Bike lanes infrastructure and usage is dependant on weather conditions and seasons
I'm open to consideration of losing some designated bike lanes if new meaningfully cross-cutting side-streets go bike-only.
Expanding bike infrastructure removes cars from the road making our cities quieter.
Reducing car lanes for bike lanes can make roads safer for cyclists and drivers alike.
Car lanes are essential for emergency services and public transit to move efficiently in busy areas.
Making road congestion in the hope that people choose other forms of transportation is the wrong approach to take
Car lanes on major streets support local businesses by making it easier for customers to reach them.
Where possible, the city should design bike lanes so that emergency vehicles can also use them.
Bike lanes only work/ are safe if planned across the city, connecting all streets.
Without a city spanning bike lane network everyone is put in danger.
Bike licensing and education (similar to car licensing) would legitimize cycling and make it safer
More enforcement is needed to ensure ebikes are going at safe speeds
We need more studies on how bike lanes on major roads affect traffic, safety, and businesses.
Car lanes are essential for suburban commuters who depend on driving into the city for work.
More enforcement is needed to ensure ebikes and scooters are following the rules of the road
Anything - including bike lanes -that slows down traffic is good for safety and city life.
Roadways with more car lanes support the large number of drivers who rely on their vehicles daily.
Car traffic on major roads should be prioritized for commuters and public transit flow.
Removing bike lanes may make driving through high-traffic areas smoother and safer for everyone.
Provincial oversight may help ensure consistent standards for bike lanes on major roads.
Reducing bike lanes on busy roads can improve traffic flow and reduce driver frustration.
Preserving car lanes on major streets can help reduce traffic congestion and travel times.
Keeping major roads clear of bike lanes may allow for smoother public transit routes and bus flow.
Major streets are critical for car travel, and bike lanes are better suited to quieter side streets.
Bikes are recreational things only - not major commuter tools
Removing bike lanes from busy streets could help relieve bottlenecks and reduce idling emissions.
Maintaining more car lanes could reduce the likelihood of accidents between cars and bikes.

representative_comments.content: Expanding bike infrastructure removes cars from the road making our cities quieter.
Anything - including bike lanes -that slows down traffic is good for safety and city life.
Reducing car lanes for bike lanes can make roads safer for cyclists and drivers alike.
Removing bike lanes from busy streets could help relieve bottlenecks and reduce idling emissions.
Maintaining more car lanes could reduce the likelihood of accidents between cars and bikes.
Removing bike lanes may make driving through high-traffic areas smoother and safer for everyone.
